course_title: Advanced Writing: Grammar, Syntax and Style

learning_outcomes.description: confidently identify grammatical features and patterns of contemporary written English
recognise grammatical choices that affect clarity, cohesion, and style
use your explicit knowledge of English grammar to reflect on and revise a variety of texts at both the structural and functional levels
integrate grammatical conventions to adapt, refine and polish writing for specific audiences, genres, and purposes.

assessments.task_description:
The online quizzes test how well you have understood the concepts covered in readings, lectures, and classes throughout the semester and how well you can recognise particular structures, written conventions, and potential errors.

You will complete the 7 quizzes on Blackboard for a maximum total of 30% of your overall course grade.

In each quiz, you will answer 10 randomised questions worth half a mark each for a total of 5% per quiz. At the end of semester, your lowest mark will be dropped, giving you a maximum total out of 30% based on your 6 highest quiz attempts.

Each quiz will open the same day as your lecture and remain open for 7 days, closing at 4.00 pm the following week.

The quizzes are open book. You may refer to your readings, lecture notes, and tutorial activities – as well as any other print or online resources that may help you. However, you should use authoritative sources and work independently. You must not share your answers with classmates until after the quiz closes. Make sure you are well prepared and have everything you need in front of you before you begin each quiz.

The quiz questions will be based on the following areas:

  • Quiz 1 – Word choices for readers (due 12 August)
  • Quiz 2 – Nouns & determiners (due 19 August)
  • Quiz 3 – Pronouns & adjectives (due 26 Aug)
  • Quiz 4 – Verbs & adverbs (due 9 September)
  • Quiz 5 – Function words (due 16 September)
  • Quiz 6 – Clauses & sentences (due 23 September)
  • Quiz 7 – Punctuation basics (due 28 October)


Please note: This is a class assessment item, not an assignment or exam, and you are not able to apply for an extension via the UniTask portal. If you are unwell or experiencing other disruptive circumstances, please contact your course coordinator directly to see if alternative arrangements are available.

This task has been designed to be challenging, authentic and complex. While students may use AI and/or MT technologies, successful completion of assessment in this course will require students to critically engage in specific contexts and tasks for which artificial intelligence will provide only limited support and guidance.

A failure to reference generative AI or MT use may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct.

To pass this assessment, students will be required to demonstrate detailed comprehension of their written submission independent of AI and MT tools.
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You cannot defer or apply for an extension for this assessment.
assessments.late_submission: A penalty of 10% of the maximum possible mark will be deducted per 24 hours from time submission is due for up to 7 days. After 7 days, you will receive a mark of 0.
assessments.additional_info: You cannot defer or apply for an extension for this assessment.

assessments.assessment_title: Supervised tutorial problem set – structural and stylistic analysis
assessments.task_description:
This class-based activity gives you an opportunity to apply your developing knowledge of English structure and style to a sample of published text.

In your perusal time, you will annotate a passage of text, reflecting on some of the ways the author has used words, phrases, and clauses (forms and structures) to achieve a particular style or effect. You will discuss your responses with classmates and consider what you can learn from the example to enhance your own writing and editing strategies.

The written component of this task then involves answering 3 questions about the text in paragraph form.

The reflection is worth 30% of your overall course grade.

This assessment task is to be completed in-person. The use of generative Artificial Intelligence (AI) or Machine Translation (MT) tools will not be permitted. Any attempted use of AI or MT may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct.
assessments.submission_guidelines: You cannot defer or apply for an extension for this assessment.
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You cannot defer or apply for an extension for this assessment.
assessments.late_submission: A penalty of 10% of the maximum possible mark will be deducted per 24 hours from time submission is due for up to 7 days. After 7 days, you will receive a mark of 0.
assessments.additional_info: You cannot defer or apply for an extension for this assessment.

assessments.task_description:
The final editing task gives you an opportunity to apply what you have learnt throughout the semester to an activity you might encounter in the workplace (or as a professional editor): marking up a passage of text with corrections and advice to the author.

This task is based loosely on the IPEd test for editors seeking accreditation in Australia. It's an excellent opportunity to gauge your current skill and accuracy as a writing and editing professional.

The task comprises 10 sequential blocks of text that contain a total of 30 errors or obvious weaknesses.

Your answer sheet will provide space for you to identify and describe each error or problem (for example, ‘spelling error—spell as X instead’ or ‘run-on sentence—insert semicolon’).

Each note is worth one mark for a total of 30/40 marks.

Your answer sheet will also provide space for you to re-write the entire passage to eliminate errors and improve clarity, tone, and structure, for a total of 10/40 marks.

To submit your assignment, you should upload your completed answer sheet and submit it via Turnitin. Please make sure your answers are as specific and coherent as possible. (Remember: imagine you are describing the problem to a client.)

This task has been designed to be challenging, authentic and complex. While students may use AI and/or MT technologies, successful completion of assessment in this course will require students to critically engage in specific contexts and tasks for which artificial intelligence will provide only limited support and guidance.

A failure to reference generative AI or MT use may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct.

To pass this assessment, students will be required to demonstrate detailed comprehension of their written submission independent of AI and MT tools.
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You may be able to apply for an extension.
assessments.late_submission: A penalty of 10% of the maximum possible mark will be deducted per 24 hours from time submission is due for up to 7 days. After 7 days, you will receive a mark of 0.
assessments.additional_info: You may be able to apply for an extension.

learning_activities.topic:
Week 1: Welcome to WRIT7260

  • Course overview, objectives, and assessment structure
  • Brief history of English grammar and its evolution
  • Why grammar matters for professional writers and editors

Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L03, L04
learning_activities.topic_description: Week 1: Welcome to WRIT7260 Course overview, objectives, and assessment structure Brief history of English grammar and its evolution Why grammar matters for professional writers and editors

learning_activities.topic:
Week 2: Writing for readers

This week introduces you to the principles of audience awareness and context sensitivity. It addresses the importance of word choice not only to convey meaning but also a particular persona, tone, style, and effect.


Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L03, L04
learning_activities.topic_description: Week 2: Writing for readers This week introduces you to the principles of audience awareness and context sensitivity. It addresses the importance of word choice not only to convey meaning but also a particular persona, tone, style, and effect.

learning_activities.topic:
Week 2: Making confident word choices

In this tutorial, you'll complete some hands-on activities to introduce you to English word classes and different categories of words to consider when you're choosing familiar, specific, and appropriate terminology for your readers.


Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L03, L04
learning_activities.topic_description: Week 2: Making confident word choices In this tutorial, you'll complete some hands-on activities to introduce you to English word classes and different categories of words to consider when you're choosing familiar, specific, and appropriate terminology for your readers.

learning_activities.topic:
Week 3: Determiners and nouns – the sentence subject

This week introduces you to the subject position of an English sentence by considering nouns and determiners. We’ll cover:

  • Notional vs formal characteristics of nouns and determiners
  • Noun forms and the sentence subject position/function
  • Common, proper, concrete, abstract, collective, and compound nouns
  • Count vs non-count nouns and their patterns of use
  • Determiners (articles, demonstratives, possessives, quantifiers)
  • How noun choices can impact tone, precision, and clarity

To prepare for your classes, read The Writer's Diet — ‘Noun density’.


Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L03, L04
learning_activities.topic_title: Week 3: Determiners and nouns – the sentence subject
learning_activities.topic_description: Week 3: Determiners and nouns – the sentence subject This week introduces you to the subject position of an English sentence by considering nouns and determiners. We’ll cover: Notional vs formal characteristics of nouns and determiners Noun forms and the sentence subject position/function Common, proper, concrete, abstract, collective, and compound nouns Count vs non-count nouns and their patterns of use Determiners (articles, demonstratives, possessives, quantifiers) How noun choices can impact tone, precision, and clarity To prepare for your classes, read The Writer's Diet — ‘Noun density’.

learning_activities.topic:
Week 3: Using nouns effectively

In this tutorial, you'll complete some hands-on activities to help you better understand sentence subjects in English and the structure of a noun phrase. You'll practise identifying nouns in context, describing the way an author might use them to achieve different effects, and some standard conventions to master as an editor.

Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L03, L04
learning_activities.topic_description: Week 3: Using nouns effectively In this tutorial, you'll complete some hands-on activities to help you better understand sentence subjects in English and the structure of a noun phrase. You'll practise identifying nouns in context, describing the way an author might use them to achieve different effects, and some standard conventions to master as an editor.

learning_activities.topic:
Week 4: Pronouns and adjectives – the sentence object

This week introduces you to the object position of an English sentence by considering pronouns and adjectives. We’ll cover:

  • SVO word order
  • Notional vs formal characteristics of pronouns and adjectives
  • Personal, possessive, reflexive, relative, and indefinite pronouns
  • Pronoun reference, agreement, and case
  • Attributive vs predicative adjectives
  • Degrees of comparison and adjective ordering
  • Creating precision using pronouns and adjectives

To prepare for your classes, read The Writer's Diet — ‘Waste words’.

Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L03, L04
learning_activities.topic_title: Week 4: Pronouns and adjectives – the sentence object
learning_activities.topic_description: Week 4: Pronouns and adjectives – the sentence object This week introduces you to the object position of an English sentence by considering pronouns and adjectives. We’ll cover: SVO word order Notional vs formal characteristics of pronouns and adjectives Personal, possessive, reflexive, relative, and indefinite pronouns Pronoun reference, agreement, and case Attributive vs predicative adjectives Degrees of comparison and adjective ordering Creating precision using pronouns and adjectives To prepare for your classes, read The Writer's Diet — ‘Waste words’.

learning_activities.topic:
Week 4: Using pronouns and adjectives

In this tutorial, you'll complete some hands-on activities to help you integrate pronouns and adjectives into your writing. You'll practise identifying pronouns and adjectives in context, describing the way an author might use these parts of speech to add colour and precision to their writing, and some standard conventions to master as an editor.

Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L03, L04
learning_activities.topic_description: Week 4: Using pronouns and adjectives In this tutorial, you'll complete some hands-on activities to help you integrate pronouns and adjectives into your writing. You'll practise identifying pronouns and adjectives in context, describing the way an author might use these parts of speech to add colour and precision to their writing, and some standard conventions to master as an editor.

learning_activities.topic:
Week 5: Verbs – the sentence predicate

This week introduces you to the heart of an English sentence – the finite verb or predicate. We’ll cover:

  • Notional vs formal characteristics of verbs
  • Finite verbs as the core of a sentence predicate
  • Subject–verb agreement
  • Main vs auxiliary verbs
  • Verb tense and aspect
  • Regular vs irregular verb forms
  • Transitive, intransitive, and linking verbs
  • Phrasal or multi-word verbs

To prepare for your classes, read The Writer's Diet — ‘Verbal verve’.

Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L03, L04
learning_activities.topic_description: Week 5: Verbs – the sentence predicate This week introduces you to the heart of an English sentence – the finite verb or predicate. We’ll cover: Notional vs formal characteristics of verbs Finite verbs as the core of a sentence predicate Subject–verb agreement Main vs auxiliary verbs Verb tense and aspect Regular vs irregular verb forms Transitive, intransitive, and linking verbs Phrasal or multi-word verbs To prepare for your classes, read The Writer's Diet — ‘Verbal verve’.

learning_activities.topic:
Week 5: Using verbs

In this tutorial, you'll complete some hands-on activities to help you integrate verbs into your writing. You'll practise identifying finite and non-finite verbs in context, as well as understanding the structure of a verb phrase, describing the way an author might manipulate verb tense and aspect in their writing, and applying standard conventions as an editor.

Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L03, L04
learning_activities.topic_description: Week 5: Using verbs In this tutorial, you'll complete some hands-on activities to help you integrate verbs into your writing. You'll practise identifying finite and non-finite verbs in context, as well as understanding the structure of a verb phrase, describing the way an author might manipulate verb tense and aspect in their writing, and applying standard conventions as an editor.

learning_activities.topic:
Week 6: Verbs and verbals – continued

This week continues our journey through English verbs, the most pivotal part of an English sentence. We’ll cover:

  • Active vs passive voice
  • Non-finite verb forms and their surprising functions
  • Adverb types and functions
  • Adverb placement and its effect on clarity/meaning
  • Using adverbs wisely
  • 3 common modifier problems and how to avoid them

To prepare for your classes, read The Writer's Diet — ‘Ad-dictions’.

Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L03, L04
learning_activities.topic_description: Week 6: Verbs and verbals – continued This week continues our journey through English verbs, the most pivotal part of an English sentence. We’ll cover: Active vs passive voice Non-finite verb forms and their surprising functions Adverb types and functions Adverb placement and its effect on clarity/meaning Using adverbs wisely 3 common modifier problems and how to avoid them To prepare for your classes, read The Writer's Diet — ‘Ad-dictions’.

learning_activities.topic:
Week 6: Understanding voice and using non-finite verb forms

In this tutorial, you'll consider the communicative options available to you when choosing between active and passive voice. You'll practise identifying non-finite verb forms in context and the ways they add extra action, dynamism, and dimension to our sentences. You'll also consider the ways authors manipulate verb phrases in their writing – and some additional conventions to be aware of as an editor.

Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L03, L04
learning_activities.topic_title: Week 6: Understanding voice and using non-finite verb forms
learning_activities.topic_description: Week 6: Understanding voice and using non-finite verb forms In this tutorial, you'll consider the communicative options available to you when choosing between active and passive voice. You'll practise identifying non-finite verb forms in context and the ways they add extra action, dynamism, and dimension to our sentences. You'll also consider the ways authors manipulate verb phrases in their writing – and some additional conventions to be aware of as an editor.

learning_activities.topic:
Week 7: Connections and relationships – English function words

This week, we’re expanding our sentences by considering two function words that establish relationships. We’ll cover:

  • Preposition types and functions, including collocations
  • Common preposition problems and areas of confusion
  • Coordinating, subordinating, and correlative conjunctions
  • Conjunctive adverbs
  • How prepositions and conjunctions affect sentence flow

To prepare for your classes, read The Writer's Diet — ‘Prepositional podge’.

Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L03, L04
learning_activities.topic_title: Week 7: Connections and relationships – English function words
learning_activities.topic_description: Week 7: Connections and relationships – English function words This week, we’re expanding our sentences by considering two function words that establish relationships. We’ll cover: Preposition types and functions, including collocations Common preposition problems and areas of confusion Coordinating, subordinating, and correlative conjunctions Conjunctive adverbs How prepositions and conjunctions affect sentence flow To prepare for your classes, read The Writer's Diet — ‘Prepositional podge’.

learning_activities.topic:
Week 7: Using function words

In this tutorial, you'll practise expanding and combining clauses by using prepositional phrases and coordinating/subordinating conjunctions. You'll work on identifying different sentence types and consider how authors play with sentence structure to achieve a variety of semantic and aesthetic effects in their writing. You'll also practise editing writing at the sentence level to resolve common errors and weaknesses.

Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L03, L04
learning_activities.topic_description: Week 7: Using function words In this tutorial, you'll practise expanding and combining clauses by using prepositional phrases and coordinating/subordinating conjunctions. You'll work on identifying different sentence types and consider how authors play with sentence structure to achieve a variety of semantic and aesthetic effects in their writing. You'll also practise editing writing at the sentence level to resolve common errors and weaknesses.

learning_activities.topic:
Week 8: Clauses and sentences

This week, we’re putting our learning together to explore clauses and the building blocks of larger sentences. We’ll cover:

  • Independent and dependent clauses
  • Restrictive vs non-restrictive clauses
  • Simple, compound, complex, and compound-complex sentences
  • Sentence weight and branching
  • Creating sentence variety

To prepare for your classes, read ThoughtCo ‘Sentence Definition and Examples in English Grammar’ (Bb).

Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L03, L04
learning_activities.topic_description: Week 8: Clauses and sentences This week, we’re putting our learning together to explore clauses and the building blocks of larger sentences. We’ll cover: Independent and dependent clauses Restrictive vs non-restrictive clauses Simple, compound, complex, and compound-complex sentences Sentence weight and branching Creating sentence variety To prepare for your classes, read ThoughtCo ‘Sentence Definition and Examples in English Grammar’ (Bb).

learning_activities.topic:
Week 8: Writing sentences

Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L03, L04
learning_activities.topic_description: Week 8: Writing sentences

learning_activities.topic:
Week 10: Tutorial problem set

In this tutorial, you'll complete your in-class assessment activity: analysing, discussing, and responding to a passage of text.

Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L03, L04
learning_activities.topic_description: Week 10: Tutorial problem set In this tutorial, you'll complete your in-class assessment activity: analysing, discussing, and responding to a passage of text.

learning_activities.topic:
Week 11: Sentences in sequence

This week, we’re looking at ways to refine and combine sentences, exploring what makes a text clear, coherent, and cohesive. We’ll cover:

  • Common sentence-level errors in carefully edited text
  • Natural paragraph variation across text types
  • Achieving clarity, coherence, and cohesion at the macro level
  • Elements of style

To prepare for your classes, start reading The Briefest Grammar and Punctuation Guide Ever!

Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L03, L04
learning_activities.topic_description: Week 11: Sentences in sequence This week, we’re looking at ways to refine and combine sentences, exploring what makes a text clear, coherent, and cohesive. We’ll cover: Common sentence-level errors in carefully edited text Natural paragraph variation across text types Achieving clarity, coherence, and cohesion at the macro level Elements of style To prepare for your classes, start reading The Briefest Grammar and Punctuation Guide Ever!

learning_activities.topic:
Week 11: Writing and editing at the paragraph level

In this tutorial, you'll sharpen your writing and editing skills by considering coherence and cohesion when combining sentences. You'll then apply your knowledge of common sentence-level errors to refine passages of text for different audiences and purposes.

Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L03, L04
learning_activities.topic_title: Week 11: Writing and editing at the paragraph level
learning_activities.topic_description: Week 11: Writing and editing at the paragraph level In this tutorial, you'll sharpen your writing and editing skills by considering coherence and cohesion when combining sentences. You'll then apply your knowledge of common sentence-level errors to refine passages of text for different audiences and purposes.

learning_activities.topic:
Week 12: Words on the page

This week, we’re looking at punctuation and formatting. We’ll cover:

  • Punctuation basics for professional writers and editors
  • Accessibility conventions in contemporary edited English
  • Principles of sound document design

To prepare for your classes, finish reading The Briefest Grammar and Punctuation Guide Ever!

Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L03, L04
learning_activities.topic_description: Week 12: Words on the page This week, we’re looking at punctuation and formatting. We’ll cover: Punctuation basics for professional writers and editors Accessibility conventions in contemporary edited English Principles of sound document design To prepare for your classes, finish reading The Briefest Grammar and Punctuation Guide Ever!

learning_activities.topic:
Week 12: Copyediting to strengthen punctuation

In this tutorial, you'll get some hands-on experience editing passages of text to make sure their punctuation is accurate, consistent, and elegant.

Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L03, L04
learning_activities.topic_description: Week 12: Copyediting to strengthen punctuation In this tutorial, you'll get some hands-on experience editing passages of text to make sure their punctuation is accurate, consistent, and elegant.

learning_activities.topic:
Week 13: Course reflection and advanced stylistic techniques

In this final lecture, we'll reflect on our learning this semester and consider the value of explicit knowledge of grammar as a part of our writing and editing toolkits.

Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L03, L04
learning_activities.topic_title: Week 13: Course reflection and advanced stylistic techniques
learning_activities.topic_description: Week 13: Course reflection and advanced stylistic techniques In this final lecture, we'll reflect on our learning this semester and consider the value of explicit knowledge of grammar as a part of our writing and editing toolkits.

learning_activities.topic:
Week 13: Course reflection and editing workshop

In this tutorial, you'll look back over your semester of learning and work through an editing task, to prepare you for your final assessment item in the course.

Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L03, L04
learning_activities.topic_description: Week 13: Course reflection and editing workshop In this tutorial, you'll look back over your semester of learning and work through an editing task, to prepare you for your final assessment item in the course.
